caseTitle: COMPTROLLER OF CUSTOMS AND EXCISE VERSUS AKAM AND OTHERS.
summary: The Comptroller of Customs and Excise sought certiorari or mandamus to compel a magistrate to order forfeiture of a lorry used to transport smuggled cigarettes. The magistrate had refused forfeiture on equity grounds, believing he had discretion under s.232 of the Customs Ordinance. The Supreme Court held that when ss.203 and 232 are read together, the word 'may' in s.232 must be interpreted as 'must', making forfeiture mandatory. However, the court refused both remedies: mandamus was inappropriate because the magistrate had exercised jurisdiction, and certiorari did not lie because the error was a mere misinterpretation of law within jurisdiction, not an excess of it. The applicant should have appealed instead. The lorry was ordered released.
verdict: Application for certiorari and mandamus refused.

jurisdiction.court: Supreme Court of the Gold Coast

citations: De Keyser v. British Railway Traffic and Electric Co. Ltd. [1936] 1 K.B. 224
Customs Ordinance, c. 167 of 1951, ss. 203 and 232
Customs Consolidation Act, 1876 (39 & 40 Vict. c. 36), ss. 202 and 226
Halsbury, Hailsham ed., Vol. 9, p. 888, para. 1493
Halsbury, Hailsham ed., Vol. 9, p. 773, para. 1309
rationaleHighlights: Sections 203 and 232 of the Customs Ordinance read together make forfeiture mandatory, not discretionary
Use of 'may' in s.232 must be interpreted as 'must' when read with s.203
Magistrate misconstrued the law but did not exceed jurisdiction
Certiorari does not lie for mere errors of law within jurisdiction
Mandamus inappropriate as magistrate exercised jurisdiction
confidenceNotes: High confidence in legal interpretation based on direct precedent (De Keyser) and statutory analysis. Jurisdictional limitations on certiorari are well-supported by Halsbury.
